elements.title: Executive Compensation - Note 13: Compensation Plans

data.value: In December 2021, each senior executive was granted RSUs with a grant date fair value of $8.2 million and a three-year cliff vesting schedule.

Also in December 2021, performance stock units (PSUs) were granted with a target fair market value of $8.2 million. The PSU plan has a three-year service period and performance measures for fiscal 2021 through fiscal 2023 based on Return on Tangible Equity (ROTE) thresholds: below 7.5% results in forfeiture, 7.5% yields 75% of target PSUs, and 15% or greater yields 150% of target PSUs; linear interpolation applies between thresholds.

A special long-term, five-year retention grant, termed the Leadership Continuity Grant, was awarded with a grant date fair value of $25.0 million. Benefits are received after an additional three-year holding period following the five-year service period.

The accompanying table details movements in restricted stock (grants, forfeitures, and vesting fulfillments) from November 30, 2019 to November 30, 2022. It shows an increase in restricted stock from 2,008 to 2,139, with an upward trend in weighted-average fair values from $22.04 to $27.85.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Compensation Plans

data.value: The table shows RSU activity with target shares decreasing from 6,491 in 2019 to 1,971 in 2022, while the average grant date fair value increased from $23.13 to $28.16. Detailed transactions include grants, forfeitures, and fulfillment of vesting requirements.

During the years ended November 30, 2022, 2021, and 2020, grants included approximately 67,000, 74,000, and 139,000 dividend equivalents declared on RSUs, with weighted-average grant date fair values of about $28.67, $29.81, and $15.82 respectively.
In the year ended November 30, 2020, grants included around 48,000 RSUs issued due to superior performance pursuant to the 2016 compensation year award.
The Compensation Committee approved 934,718 RSUs in December 2022 relating to above target performance earned under the compensation year 2020 Plan.

For the senior executive stock options issued during the year ended November 30, 2021, the weighted-average assumptions were: Date: November 30, 2021; Risk-free interest rate: 0.8%; Expected volatility: 32.9%; Expected dividend yield: 2.6%; Expected life: 5.8 years; Weighted-average fair value per grant: $7.43.
The fair value of stock option awards is estimated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model, while excess dividend rights are valued using a Monte Carlo simulation.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Compensation Plans

data.value: Implemented under both the prior Incentive Plan and the new ECP. Considered noncompensatory effective January 1, 2007, it allows eligible employees to make payroll contributions to acquire shares at a discounted price.

Implemented under both the prior Incentive Plan and the new ECP. It permits eligible employees to defer compensation, which may be invested in common shares at a discount or other available investment vehicles. The deferred compensation is expensed in the period earned, with changes in fair value of related investments recognized in principal transaction revenues and adjustments reflected as compensation and benefits expense.

In connection with the HomeFed merger in 2019, each HomeFed stock option was converted into an option to purchase two common shares. Designated share amounts for these options were reported at different dates (e.g., 12,000 in 2022, 96,000 in 2021, and 313,000 in 2020).

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Organization and Significant Accounting Policies

data.value: The document explains that all entities under control, including those defined as variable interest entities (VIEs), are consolidated. For less than wholly-owned entities, noncontrolling interests are separately presented.

Customer securities transactions are reported on a settlement date basis with income recognized on a trade-date basis. Soft dollar arrangements are netted against commission revenues and asset-based fees are recorded for asset management and account services.
Financial instruments owned and those sold (not yet purchased) are carried at fair value with gains and losses reflected in Principal transactions revenues, except for derivatives used as hedges.

Advisory fees from mergers and acquisitions engagements are recognized at the point when the related transaction is completed, while advisory fees from restructuring engagements are recognized over time in line with progress. Associated reimbursable expenses are deferred as applicable.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, continued - Summary of Significant Accounting Policies

data.value: Recognized at a point in time on trade-date. Associated underwriting costs are deferred until the related revenue is recognized and recorded on a gross basis.

Include asset management fees and revenues from third-parties with strategic relationships. Fees from third-parties are recognized at the end of the defined revenue or profit share period after realization and resolution of all contingencies.
Generally recognized over the period during which the related service is provided.
Recognized only at the end of the performance period to the extent that the benchmark return has been met.

Contractual interest is recognized on an accrual basis for owned financial instruments and those sold but not yet purchased. Interest flows on derivatives and dividends are included in Principal transactions revenues rather than as a component of interest revenue or expense.

Short- and long-term borrowings are accounted for at amortized cost (except those using the fair value option) with interest recorded on an accrual basis. Discounts/premiums on long-term debt are accreted/amortized using the effective yield method over the remaining life of the debt.

Interest revenue related to securities borrowed and purchased under repurchase agreements, and interest expense related to securities loaned and sold under such agreements, are recognized on an accrual basis. Additional interest income and expense are recognized on brokerage customer margin balances and credit balances, respectively.

Includes revenue from the sale of manufactured or remanufactured lumber, produced oil and gas, and real estate. Revenue recognition criteria depend on transfer of control, completion of performance obligations, and reliable estimation of variable consideration.
Defined as highly liquid investments, including money market funds and certificates of deposit, not held for resale, with original maturities of three months or less.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Significant Accounting Policies and Fair Value Measurement

data.value: Describes how Jefferies LLC and other entities maintain segregated cash or qualified securities in reserve accounts for regulatory purposes in accordance with Rule 15c3-3 and other regulatory mandates.

Financial instruments owned and sold (but not yet purchased) are recorded at fair value, using either accounting standards requirements or the fair value option election, with impacts on trading revenues.

Instruments are categorized into Levels 1, 2, and 3 based on the transparency of pricing inputs. Level 1 uses quoted prices; Level 2 includes observable pricing inputs from less active markets or derived via models; Level 3 relies on management’s best estimates.
For instruments based on bid-ask spreads, valuation is determined at the point in the range that best reflects fair value at the measurement date.
Emphasis is on maximizing observable inputs and minimizing unobservable ones, ensuring market data from independent sources is primarily used for valuation.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, continued

data.key: Investments in and Loans to Related Parties
data.value: Include investments in private equity and other operating entities where significant influence is exercised, accounted for using the equity method or at cost, and reviewed for impairment when necessary. Revenues are included in Other revenues.

Financial assets measured at amortized cost are presented at the net amount expected to be collected. Expected credit losses are estimated over the life of the financial instrument based on judgment, current market conditions, and forecasts.

Represents the excess acquisition cost over the fair value of net tangible and intangible assets. Goodwill is not amortized and is subject to annual impairment testing at the reporting unit level using fair value estimates.

Finite-life intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives and reviewed for impairment. Intangible assets with indefinite lives are not amortized but are assessed for impairment annually or more frequently if circumstances indicate potential impairment.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Significant Accounting Policies

data.value: If it is determined that it is not more likely than not that an impairment exists, a quantitative impairment test is not required; otherwise, a quantitative impairment test must be performed.

Intangible assets are included in Other assets with an annual indefinite-lived impairment testing date of August 1st; impairment loss, if recognized, sets the new cost basis and is amortized over the remaining useful life.

Premises and equipment are depreciated using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives (generally three to ten years). Internally developed software ready for use is also depreciated over its remaining useful life.
At November 30, 2022, the carrying value amounted to $730.1 million (2021: $728.3 million).

Lease liabilities are recognized at the present value of future minimum lease payments, with corresponding right-of-use assets adjusted for prepayments, initial direct costs and lease incentives; lease expense is recognized on a straight-line basis.
Expenditures incurred in property acquisition, development, and construction are classified within Other assets, with costs capitalized including interest, payroll, taxes, and professional fees.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Note 4. Fair Value Disclosures

data.value: The note explains the valuation basis and techniques used to measure financial assets and liabilities at fair value on a recurring basis.

Exchange-traded equity securities are measured based on quoted closing prices (Level 1 generally, otherwise Level 2) without valuation adjustments if actively traded. Non-exchange-traded equity securities use broker quotations, external pricing data, recent market transactions, and when unavailable, rely on valuation techniques such as comparable company analysis, multiples (e.g., price/EBITDA, price/book), discounted cash flows, and observed transaction prices (categorized as Level 2 or Level 3).

Non-exchange-traded equity warrants are primarily measured from recent market transactions and broker quotations (Level 2) or, if needed, via third-party valuation services or the Black-Scholes model (Level 3) with key inputs such as underlying security price, implied volatility, dividend yield, interest rate curve, strike price, and maturity date.

Investment grade corporate bonds are valued using pricing data from external services, broker quotes, recent market transactions, and bond spreads, categorized as Level 2 or Level 3. A significant portion of high yield corporate and convertible bonds is measured using broker quotations and external pricing data (Level 2) or, if less observable, based on pending transactions and modeled assumptions (Level 3).

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Fair Value Disclosures & Derivative Financial Instruments

data.value: The note explains that certain financial instruments are not carried at fair value but are recorded at amounts that approximate fair value, due to their liquid or short-term nature and negligible credit risk. It also describes the accounting treatment of equity securities without readily determinable fair values, which are accounted for at cost minus impairment.

At November 30, 2022 and 2021, equity securities recorded at cost (minus impairment) were reported as $37.0 million and $119.4 million respectively. No impairments were recorded in 2022 and 2021, while an impairment of $20.4 million was recognized in 2020. Realized gains of $3.6 million (2022), $0.8 million (2021) and $2.1 million (2020) were reported with no unrealized gains or losses.

Derivatives are recorded at fair value, net of cash and counterparty netting, as part of financial instruments owned and sold. The derivatives are used to meet client needs and manage market and credit risks and include hedge accounting for interest rate swaps and forward foreign exchange contracts.

The note details that derivative activities are subject to market, credit, and operational risks. These risks are managed on an aggregate basis alongside other trading-related activities under firm-wide risk management policies.

data.value: Securities lending arrangements and Repurchase agreements

This table presents a breakdown of securities lending arrangements and repurchase agreements across different time periods. The total value is approximately $17.55 billion, with the largest portion ($7.15 billion) in overnight and continuous arrangements, followed by 31-90 days ($4.90 billion) and greater than 90 days ($3.70 billion).

The table appears to be extracted from a financial statement, showing securities lending and repurchase agreement maturities. Some values may have been merged or split across rows in the original format. Values are in thousands of dollars.

We receive securities as collateral under resale agreements, securities borrowing transactions, customer margin loans, as initial margin on certain derivative transactions and in connection with securities-for-securities transactions in which we are the lender of securities. In many instances, we are permitted by contract to rehypothecate the securities received as collateral.
At November 30, 2022 and 2021, the approximate fair value of securities received as collateral by us that may be sold or repledged was $26.82 billion and $31.97 billion, respectively.

To manage our exposure to credit risk associated with securities financing transactions, we may enter into master netting agreements and collateral arrangements with counterparties. Transactions are executed under standard industry agreements, including master securities lending agreements and master repurchase agreements. See Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, for additional information.

data.value: This section presents a rollforward of the allowance for credit losses related to automobile loans for the years ended November 30, 2022, 2021, and 2020. It includes data on beginning balances, adjustments for changes in accounting principles, provisions for doubtful accounts, charge-offs (net of recoveries), and ending balances.

The movement in credit loss allowance shows beginning balances of 23,606 (2020), 29,710 (2021), and 67,236 (2022), with a notable one-time adjustment in 2021 for current expected credit losses (30,148). Provisions and charge-offs further adjust the balances, resulting in ending balances of 29,710 (2020), 67,236 (2021), and 79,614 (2022).

This table provides a breakdown of automobile loans by credit score at origination. Key points: 16.3% of the portfolio has credit scores of 680 and above, 46.3% falls between 620 to 679, and 37.4% has scores below 620. The total portfolio value reached 879,226 with significant increases in recent years.

A similar analysis for 2021 shows a slightly different distribution with 19.49% for scores 680 and above, 50.6% for scores between 620 to 679, and 30.0% for scores below 620, with a total portfolio value of 801,687. Growth in lending activity is evident over the years.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Revenue Recognition and Related Expenses

data.value: Revenues from contracts with customers are recognized at a point in time upon achieving specified milestones, with variable consideration excluded until associated uncertainties are resolved.
Payment for advisory services is due promptly upon milestone completion or periodically for retainer fees, with receivables recognized between milestone completion and customer payment.
Expenses related to investment banking advisory engagements are deferred only to the extent they are explicitly reimbursable by the client; all non-reimbursable expenses are expensed as incurred.

Underwriting and placement agent revenues, including equity and debt capital market transactions, are recognized on trade-date, with associated costs deferred until revenue recognition or engagement conclusion.

Commission revenues from trade execution and clearing services are recognized at a point in time on trade-date, with soft dollar arrangements netted against commissions. Investment research and advisory fees are recognized over time or at the point of individual interactions.
Account advisory fees in wealth management services are recognized over time using the time-elapsed method, with fees paid in advance being deferred.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements - Revenue Recognition Policies

data.value: Management and performance fees are earned in connection with investment advisory services provided to various funds and accounts. These fees are recognized over time, based on a time elapsed measure that reflects service delivery as benefits are provided continuously over the contract term. The fees are variable and contingent on factors such as assets under management and market performance, and are recognized only when it is probable that no significant reversal will occur.
Revenues from the sale of manufactured or remanufactured lumber are recognized at a fixed transaction price once the customer obtains control of the product.

Oil and natural gas sales include variable consideration linked to monthly pricing indices and production volumes. Revenue is recorded at the point in time when control transfers to the customer, using estimated production reports and market data to measure the transaction price.

Revenues from real estate sales are recognized when the transaction is complete, typically at the close of escrow when title transfers. If related performance obligations are incomplete, revenue is deferred until completion.

elements.title: JEFFERIES 2022 ANNUAL REPORT – Observations as We Proceed in 2023

data.value: JEFFERIES 2022 ANNUAL REPORT
Be Aware and Wary of the Macro Forces, But Focus On What You Can Effect

Global pandemic, active European war, tension between major world powers, storming of the U.S. Capitol Building, dramatic declines in risk asset prices, raging inflation, massive interest rate increases, and freezing of equity and leveraged finance new issue markets
Past three-plus decades with focus on the 2020s and outlook for 2023
Strong capital foundation, robust risk systems, self-imposed limits and diversification across product, service, sector and geography; emphasis on a solid cultural foundation
Acceptance of ongoing volatility and challenges with a focus on identifying opportunities amidst macro risks

elements.title: Risk Factors Affecting Our Business

data.value: JFSI complies with SEC's net capital requirements, and is subject to regulations by several international regulatory bodies.
The business faces significant credit risk due to execution, settlement, financing of various customer and principal transactions.
Business operations may be affected by global/regional economic, business, political changes, acts of war, terrorism, pandemics, climate change, and natural disasters.
Transactions are subject to counterparty/customer nonperformance risk and market value changes of collateral.
Compliance with anti-money laundering and anti-bribery rules is mandated.

elements.title: Risk Management Overview

data.value: We seek to control the risk associated with transactions by establishing credit limits and monitoring collateral.

Fluctuations in interest rates, equity prices, and credit quality.
A downgrade could negatively impact our business and ability to access capital markets.

Disruptions in markets may affect the ability to sell or realize security values.

elements.title: IBOR Transition and LIBOR Discontinuance Risks

data.value: The document outlines risks related to changes in or the discontinuance of IBORs – particularly LIBOR – including pricing volatility, market share loss, adverse tax/accounting impacts, compliance and legal costs, and potential litigation.
Central banks and regulators in major jurisdictions, along with groups such as NWG, ARRC, ISDA, and others, are working towards transitioning to appropriate replacement rates and fallback provisions.
U.S. Dollar LIBOR one-week and two-month maturities ceased on January 1, 2022; remaining U.S. Dollar LIBOR maturities will cease immediately after June 30, 2023.
Reducing overall exposure to LIBOR, implementing fallback provisions in new contracts, client education on transition, contract remediation, and planning fallback mechanisms.
Uncertainty in IBOR transitions may lead to increased capital requirements, pricing volatility, operational disruptions, and client disputes or litigation.

Unprecedented volatility in global financial markets and reductions in revenue across businesses.
Potential regulatory scrutiny of the ability to adequately supervise activities in accordance with applicable requirements.

elements.title: Contingency Funding Plan, Cash Capital Policy and MLO Parameters

data.value: Based on a model of potential liquidity contraction over a one-year period. It addresses potential cash outflows during market or idiosyncratic liquidity stress events, such as repayment of unsecured debt, rollover of letters of credit, higher margin requirements, liquidity outflows from credit downgrades, reduced availability of secured funding, client cash withdrawals, funding of outstanding commitments, and other liabilities.

A model that measures long-term funding sources (including equity, mezzanine equity, and noncurrent portion of long-term borrowings) against cash capital requirements. It outlines the uses of cash capital for illiquid assets, portion of securities inventory, and unfunded commitments, aiming to maintain surplus cash capital.

Calculated during liquidity stress based on a combined market-wide and firm-specific stress scenario. The scenario includes elements such as a global recession, credit rating downgrades (two-notch downgrade of long-term senior unsecured ratings), defaults by medium-sized sovereigns, low confidence levels, equity market declines, widening credit spreads, and potential failures of large banks due to adverse follow-on impacts.
Includes liquidity needs over a 30-day scenario and assumptions of a two-notch downgrade in credit ratings.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Summary of Significant Accounting Policies

data.value: Valuation of Financial Instruments and Securities Financing

The note discusses the use of valuation models and management's judgment in adjusting valuations for financial instruments, particularly when inputs are unobservable, leading to higher subjectivity in Level 3 instruments. It also outlines the accounting treatment for securities borrowed, securities loaned, and repurchase agreements (repos), including collateral management and interest recognition.

Highlights uncertainties regarding market conditions; the variability of observable inputs; and the potential for transfers among fair value hierarchy levels due to changes in observability, which are all factors that introduce risk in measuring fair value.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Summary of Significant Accounting Policies

data.value: Describe arrangements such as master securities lending and repurchase agreements that aggregate trades into a single net payment obligation, provide protection in bankruptcy, and allow offsetting of receivables and payables.

Under ISDA master netting agreements, credit support annexes require collateral—either cash or securities—based on the fair value of derivative receivables or payables, with provisions for liquidation and application against net obligations.

The enforceability of netting agreements depends on contract law and bankruptcy laws in different jurisdictions; industry legal opinions are used to manage counterparty credit risk and liquidity risk.
Clearing arrangements with central counterparties facilitate net settlement and daily cash deposits only to the extent of the net amount, with provisions in the event of counterparty default.

Activities include transferring corporate, consumer, and mortgage loans to secured funding vehicles, where transfers are accounted for as sales if control is relinquished, or as secured borrowings if criteria are not met.

data.value: This note discloses detailed netting arrangements and collateral positions related to various securities transactions. It outlines gross positions, netting adjustments, additional setoffs, available collateral, and final net exposures for transactions such as securities borrowing arrangements, reverse repurchase agreements, securities lending arrangements, repurchase agreements, and obligations to return securities received as collateral.

For the 2022 period, the largest gross position was reported in repurchase agreements (approximately $13.6B) followed by reverse repurchase agreements (approximately $10.7B). After applying netting provisions and adjusting for collateral, securities borrowing arrangements ended with the largest final net exposure (approximately $4.16B).

For the 2021 period, repurchase agreements ($16.0B gross) and reverse repurchase agreements ($15.2B gross) were the largest positions. The final net exposures were significantly reduced after netting adjustments and collateral considerations, with repurchase agreements showing a net amount of approximately $769.2M.

The tables and accompanying disclosures highlight the use of master netting agreements, collateral arrangements, and additional setoffs as credit risk mitigation measures. These arrangements, though not fully netted under U.S. GAAP due to legal enforceability concerns, serve to reduce overall counterparty exposure in the event of default.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements – Summary of Significant Accounting Policies and Legal Reserves

data.value: The company uses a two-step process to evaluate uncertain tax positions: first, determining if it is more likely than not that each position will be sustained based on technical merits, and second, recognizing the largest tax benefit that is more than 50% likely to be realized upon settlement. A portfolio approach is used with respect to the release of stranded tax effects recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss).

Basic EPS is computed by dividing net earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares and other committed shares. Diluted EPS adjusts the numerator and denominator for dilutive securities, including adjustments for restricted stock and RSUs, with distinctions made for participating versus non-participating securities.

The company is periodically named as a defendant in legal and regulatory proceedings and undergoes governmental and self-regulatory reviews. It recognizes liabilities for potential losses in accrued expenses and other liabilities when a loss is probable and can be reasonably estimated, accruing the most likely or minimum amount if a range is provided.
